The mRNA vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna are a new type of vaccine that use a unique approach to trigger an immune response. Instead of using a weakened or inactive virus to stimulate the body's immune system, these vaccines use a molecule called messenger RNA (mRNA) that contains a code for making a protein that is found on the surface of the coronavirus.

When the vaccine is injected into the body, the mRNA molecules enter the cells and instruct them to make the coronavirus protein. This protein is then displayed on the surface of the cells, where it is recognized as foreign by the immune system. The immune system mounts an attack against the protein, creating antibodies and other immune cells that will recognize and destroy the coronavirus if it ever enters the body in the future.

The mRNA molecules themselves do not change the DNA of the body's cells or cause any long-term effects. After the protein is made and the immune response is triggered, the mRNA is broken down and cleared from the body.

This approach has several advantages over traditional vaccine methods. First, it can be developed and manufactured more quickly than traditional vaccines since it uses only the genetic code of the virus rather than trying to grow and purify the virus itself. Second, it is highly scalable and can be easily modified to target different strains of the virus or other infectious diseases. Finally, it has shown high efficacy in clinical trials, with both Pfizer and Moderna reporting over 90% effectiveness in preventing COVID-19 infection.

Herd immunity occurs when a significant proportion of a population becomes immune to a contagious disease, either through previous exposure or vaccination, making it difficult for the disease to spread within the population. This leads to the protection of even those individuals who are not immune.

Polio and smallpox are both highly contagious viral diseases that were once prevalent worldwide, causing significant illness, disability, and death. While efforts to achieve herd immunity through natural exposure were made, these strategies were ineffective at controlling the spread of the diseases.

Vaccines, on the other hand, contain weakened or dead strains of the virus. When injected into a person's body, their immune system recognizes the virus as foreign and mounts an immune response to destroy it. After this, the immune system retains a memory of the virus, allowing it to recognize and combat it if it ever infects the body again. By vaccinating a large proportion of a population, it is possible to establish herd immunity and ultimately eradicate the disease.

Therefore, polio and smallpox were not eradicated solely by achieving herd immunity, but rather through the widespread use of vaccines. These vaccines effectively broke the transmission cycle of the viruses and prevented further outbreaks, ultimately leading to the eradication of these deadly diseases.
